resources.string: Start with variables, data types, and operators

On the first day, focus on programming language fundamentals. Learn: how to declare variables, basic data types (strings, numbers, booleans), arithmetic and logical operators. Create a simple "Hello World" program and experiment with outputting different values to the screen.
Learn if, else if, else, and switch-case

Conditional statements are the foundation of program logic. Practice writing conditions: if, else if, else, switch-case (or match, depending on the language). Solve several condition-checking tasks, for example: "determine if a number is even," "find the maximum of three numbers."
Learn for, while, and do-while loops

Loops allow you to repeat actions. Learn different types of loops: for, while, do-while. Write a program that outputs numbers from 1 to 10, calculates the sum of numbers in a range, finds the factorial of a number. Understand the differences between loops and when to use each.
Learn to create and use functions

Functions are building blocks of programs. Learn: declaring functions, passing parameters, returning values. Create functions for frequently repeated actions: calculating areas of shapes, converting units of measurement, checking prime numbers. Understand the concept of variable scope.

Arrays and lists store collections of data. Learn: creating arrays/lists, adding/removing elements, iterating through collections. Solve problems: find the maximum element in an array, calculate average value, sort an array, find duplicates. Learn basic collection methods.

Strings are one of the most used data structures. Learn: concatenation, substring search, text replacement, splitting strings, case operations. Write programs: counting words in text, checking palindromes, Caesar cipher. Learn regular expressions for complex search operations.
Get acquainted with classes and objects

OOP is a key programming paradigm. Learn: classes and objects, constructors, methods, fields. Create a "Student" class with fields: name, age, grades. Add methods for calculating average grade, displaying information. Understand the difference between class and object.

Continue learning OOP: inheritance, polymorphism, encapsulation. Create a class hierarchy: Shape → Circle/Square/Triangle. Implement a common "calculate area" method that will work differently for each shape. Learn abstract classes and interfaces.
Learn to handle errors in code

Exceptions help handle errors. Learn: try-catch-finally blocks, creating custom exceptions. Write a program with error handling: division by zero, array index out of bounds, incorrect user input. Learn the difference between checked and unchecked exceptions.
Learn to read and write files

File operations are an important skill. Learn: reading text files, writing data to files, checking file existence. Create programs: a diary where you can add entries and read old ones; file copying; counting lines in a text file.

Start learning data structures with stack (LIFO) and queue (FIFO). Implement them yourself using arrays/lists. Solve problems: checking bracket correctness using a stack, simulating a bank queue. Understand where these structures are used in real applications.

Recursion is a function that calls itself. Learn: base case, recursive case. Write recursive functions: calculating factorial, Fibonacci numbers, binary search. Understand the advantages and disadvantages of recursion, learn about stack overflow and tail recursion optimization.

Sorting algorithms are the foundation of programming. Implement: bubble sort (simple but slow), quicksort (efficient). Compare their performance on different datasets. Understand time complexity O(n²) vs O(n log n).

Learn two main search algorithms: linear (sequential) and binary. Implement both algorithms. Understand when to use each: binary search works only on sorted arrays but is much faster. Compare complexity O(n) and O(log n).

Git is a must-have tool for programmers. Install Git, create an account on GitHub/GitLab. Learn basic commands: init, add, commit, push, pull, clone, branch. Create your first repository, add a README file. Understand the concept of branching and merging.

Databases store information. Install SQLite or PostgreSQL. Learn SQL: CREATE TABLE, INSERT, SELECT, UPDATE, DELETE. Create a database for bookkeeping: table with fields id, title, author, year. Write queries: find all books by an author, update publication year.
Learn to work with web APIs

APIs allow programs to communicate. Learn HTTP methods: GET, POST, PUT, DELETE. Using libraries (requests in Python, fetch in JS, Retrofit in Kotlin), make a request to a public API (e.g., weather, currency rates). Learn to process JSON responses.

Testing is part of professional development. Choose a testing framework (JUnit for Java, pytest for Python, Jest for JS). Write tests for a function that adds two numbers, a function that determines evenness. Learn the AAA pattern: Arrange-Act-Assert. Learn to test edge cases.
Learn to find and fix errors

Debugging is an important skill. Learn to use the debugger in your IDE: breakpoints, step-by-step execution, variable inspection. Write a program with an error (e.g., infinite loop) and find it using the debugger. Learn logging as an alternative to print debugging.

Clean code is easier to maintain. Learn principles: meaningful variable names, small functions (up to 20 lines), no code duplication (DRY). Take old code and refactor it: split a large function into several small ones, rename variables, remove dead code.

Big O notation describes algorithm efficiency. Learn: O(1) - constant time, O(n) - linear, O(n²) - quadratic, O(log n) - logarithmic. Analyze your sorting and search algorithms in terms of Big O. Understand why efficiency matters with large data.

Date operations are often required in applications. Learn date libraries (datetime in Python, java.time in Java, Date in JS). Learn: parsing dates from strings, formatting dates, calculating differences between dates, adding/subtracting intervals. Create a reminder program.

Multithreading speeds up program execution. Learn: creating threads, synchronization, race conditions. Write a program where multiple threads increment a shared counter. Verify synchronization problems, then solve them using mutexes/semaphores. Be careful with deadlock.

Regular expressions allow finding complex patterns in text. Learn basic constructs: . (any character), * (0 or more), + (1 or more), [] (set), () (group). Write regex for: email validation, phone number, password (letters+digits+special chars). Use online testers for debugging.

Create your first web page: HTML for structure, CSS for styles, JavaScript for interactivity. Make a business card page: header, paragraph about yourself, skills list, contact form. Deploy it on GitHub Pages. Learn basic HTML tags and CSS properties.

JSON is a popular format for APIs and configurations. Learn: parsing JSON strings into objects, serializing objects to JSON. Create a program that reads a JSON file with user data and outputs it in formatted form. Learn differences between JSON and XML.

Write your first script in bash/Python for automation. Examples: script for backing up files, for renaming groups of files, for checking website availability. Learn basic command line commands: ls, cd, mkdir, cp, mv, grep. Understand automation benefits.

Architectural patterns organize code. Learn MVC (Model-View-Controller) - separation into data, presentation, and logic. Create a simple application (e.g., todo list) using MVC. Understand advantages: separation of responsibility, easy testing, support for changes.
Make code faster and more efficient

Optimization improves performance. Analyze old code: find "bottlenecks." Optimize: replace linear search with binary, add caching of calculation results, avoid unnecessary calculations in loops. Measure performance before and after optimization.

Finish the month by creating a portfolio. Select 3 best projects from the month, document them: describe functionality, technologies, problems and solutions. Publish on GitHub with clear README. Create a simple portfolio website or use GitHub Pages. Portfolio is your business card for employers.
